metadata.title: 1H NMR and GC-MS based metabolomics reveal defense and detoxification mechanism of cucumber plant under nano-Cu stress

Article
1H NMR and GC-MS based metabolomics reveal defense and detoxification mechanism of cucumber plant under nano-Cu stress
Lijuan Zhao, Yuxiong Huang, Jerry Hu, Hongjun Zhou, Adeyemi S. Adeleye, and Arturo A. Keller Environ. Sci. Technol., Just Accepted Manuscript • DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05011 • Publication Date (Web): 11 Jan 2016

Page 2 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology

ABSTRACT 45
Since copper nanoparticles are being increasingly used in agriculture as pesticides, it is 46
important to assess their potential implications for agriculture. Concerns have been raised 47
about the bioaccumulation of nano-Cu and their toxicity to crop plants. Here, the 48
response of cucumber plants in hydroponic culture at early development stages to two 49
concentrations of nano-Cu (10 and 20 mg/L) was evaluated by proton nuclear magnetic 50 resonance spectroscopy (1H NMR) and Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-51
MS) based metabolomics. Changes in mineral nutrient metabolism induced by nano-Cu 52
were determined by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Results 53
showed that nano-Cu at both concentrations interfere with the uptake of a number of 54
micro- and macro-nutrients, such as Na, P, S, Mo, Zn, and Fe. Metabolomics data 55
revealed that nano-Cu at both levels triggered significant metabolic changes in cucumber 56
leaves and root exudates. The root exudate metabolic changes revealed an active defense 57
mechanism against nano-Cu stress: up-regulation of amino acids to sequester/exclude 58
Cu/nano-Cu; down-regulation of citric acids to reduce the mobilization of Cu ions; 59
ascorbic acid up-regulation to combat reactive oxygen species; up-regulation of phenolic 60 compounds to improve antioxidant system. Thus, we demonstrate that non-targeted 1H 61
NMR and GC-MS based metabolomics can successfully identify physiological responses 62
induced by nanoparticles. Root exudates metabolomics revealed important detoxification 63
mechanisms. 64
65
66
67
Page 3 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
4
INTRODUCTION 68
Copper and its compounds have been found to have the ability to inhibit fungi since 69 ancient times1 and have been used widely in agriculture as fungicides2, algaecides3, 70 pesticides4, and herbicides5. There are at least 209 pesticide products registered in 71 California that use copper oxide as an active ingredient4. In addition, due to steady 72
increase of drug resistance of bacteria, synthesis and application of novel 73 antibacterial/anti antifungal Cu nanoparticles (NPs) has increased6. Besides antibacterial 74
applications, Cu NPs (which includes nano-Cu as well as nano copper oxides) also have 75 application as additives of livestock and poultry feed7. There is increasing concern about 76
the potential for bioaccumulation and toxicity of Cu NPs after their release to the 77
environment. It has been shown in several studies that nano-Cu triggers reactive oxygen 78 species (ROS) generation and induces oxidative stress in cells, bacteria, and zebrafish8, 9. 79
However, very few studies have focused on the toxicity of Cu NPs on terrestrial plants, 80 especially crop plants. Lee et al.10, documented that Cu NPs are toxic to mung bean 81
(Phaseolus radiatus) and wheat (Triticum aestivum) at concentrations of 335 and 570 82 mg/L respectively. Hong et al.11, reported that even at the level of 5-20 mg/L, Cu NPs 83
significantly reduced the root length of alfalfa and lettuce and altered their nutrient 84
uptake. 85
Cucumber plants are generally more sensitive to contaminants and their 86
bioaccumulation is higher than many other plants due to their high transpiration rate. Our 87
previous study showed both CeO2 and ZnO NPs triggered more physiological changes in 88 cucumber plants compared to corn plants, which have lower transpiration rates12, 13. Here 89
we hypothesized that nano-Cu would induce physiological responses in cucumber plants. 90
Page 4 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
5
To evaluate this, we selected metabolomics studies, as a novel approach to understand 91 plant-nanoparticle interactions. We selected a 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR)-92
based environmental metabolomics platform to detect the induced alteration, because 93
NMR can simultaneously detect a variety of metabolites with simple sample 94 preparation14, 15. In addition, compared with other “omics”, metabolomics reveals effects 95 downstream of DNA15 and simultaneously provides a nonspecific assessment of the end 96 result of multiple biological responses16. Therefore, 1H NMR has been employed to 97
evaluate the toxicity of a large variety of environmental contaminants on different 98 organisms17-21. The toxicity and toxicity mechanism of titanium dioxide NPs to 99 earthworms16 and rats22 was evaluated via an environmental metabolomics platform using 100 1H NMR. 101
Furthermore, most previous studies of the effect of various NPs to plants have 102
concentrated on toxicity. Potential detoxification mechanisms have been less reported. It 103
is well known that approximately 30% to 40% of all photosynthetically fixed carbon will 104 be transferred to the rhizosphere23, 24 as root exudates, including organic acids, amino 105 acids, sugars, proteins, phenolic compounds, and CO2 25. These compounds play an 106 important role on plant stress tolerance and external exclusion of pollutants23. 107
Considerable evidence exists that plants up-regulate some organic acids, including amino 108
acids, to chelate or complex toxic metals (e.g., Al, Cd, Zn, Fe, Cu), to hinder their 109 translocation to aboveground plant tissues26-30. Murphy et al.31 reported copper ions 110
induce citrate production in root secretions. Our hypothesis is that root exudates may play 111
an important role in NP mobility and bioavailability, as well as up- or down-regulation of 112
metabolite levels due to toxic effects and to induce detoxification. 113
Page 5 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
6
Therefore, the aims of the present study were to investigate the uptake, translocation, 114 bioaccumulation, and toxicity of nano-Cu in cucumber tissues. We used non-targeted 1H 115
NMR and GC-MS based metabolomics to evaluate the physiological changes induced by 116
nano-Cu in cucumber plants. Mineral nutrient metabolism was also evaluated by 117
determining the elemental content in different tissues. 118
EXPERIMENTAL SECTION 119
Cu NPs. Detailed characterization of nano-Cu (U.S. Research Nanomaterials) employed 120 here is presented in a previous study32. Briefly, the primary particle size is 40 nm and the 121
hydrodynamic diameter is 2590 ± 1138 nm in deionized (DI) water, due to considerable 122
aggregation. The surface charge expressed as zeta potential is +10.9±4.0, -29.4±0.8 and -123
40.8±1.7, at pH 4, 7 and 11 respectively. 124
Seed Germination and Plant Growth. Cucumber (Cucumis sativus) seeds were surface-125
disinfected in a 4% NaClO solution for 30 min with continuous stirring, then rinsed 3 126
times with sterile nanopure water (NW), and immersed in NW for 24 hours. 127 Subsequently, the seeds were transferred to autoclaved paper towels for germination33. In 128
each paper towel, 10 drops of antibiotic solution (Sigma 5955) were added to prevent 129
fungal growth. The rolled paper towel with seeds was placed in a Mason jar with NW at 130
the bottom and kept in the dark for 4 days, followed by 1 day exposure in light. 131
After germination, the young plants were transferred to a magenta box and grown 132
hydroponically in modified Hoagland nutrient solution in a greenhouse. The temperature 133
in greenhouse was maintained at 28 °C by day and 20 °C by night. The nutrient solution 134
was renewed every 7 days. However, in between these 7-day periods, tap water was used 135
to refill the magenta boxes, to compensate for the water taken up via transpiration. In 136
Page 6 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
7
order to collect sufficient amounts of secreted compounds, the young unexposed 137
cucumber plants were allowed to grow for 2 weeks with continuous aeration. On day 14, 138
the cucumber seedlings were exposed to half strength Hoagland nutrient solution 139
containing different concentrations (0, 10, and 20 mg/L) of nano-Cu for 1 week. These 140 levels are consistent with expected concentrations from pesticide use or in biosolids34, 35. 141
Each treatment was replicated four times, and each magenta box contained 9 cucumber 142
seedlings. 143
Cu and Nutrient Elements Analysis. At harvest, the cucumber plants were thoroughly 144
washed with DI water and oven dried for 3 days at 70 °C. Dried tissues were digested 145
with a mixture of 4 ml of H2O2 and 1 ml of plasma pure HNO3 (v/v: 4:1) using a 146 microwave oven system (Multiwave Eco, Anton Par) at 180°C for 1 hour. The standard 147
reference materials (Peach leaves, NIST 1547, USA; Spinach, leaves, NIST 1570A) were 148
also digested and analyzed as samples. The recoveries for all elements were between 90 149 and 99%12. Cu and other mineral elements were analyzed using ICP-MS (6900 Agilent, 150
USA). 151
Root Exudates Collection and Analysis. The procedure for collection of root exudates 152 was modified from that described by Zhao et al.36 Specifically, at the end of exposure to 153
nano-Cu, the cucumber seedlings were removed from the magenta box, and the roots 154
were washed thoroughly with DI water. Then the seedlings were incubated in a new 155
magenta box containing 100 ml autoclaved 0.1 mM CaCl2 solution for 4 hours for root 156 exudate collection. The solution was aerated continuously during the 4 hours period of 157
collection. After 4 hours, the 0.1 mM CaCl2 solution, which now contained the secreted 158 metabolites, was filtered immediately using a syringe filter (0.45 µm) to remove all the 159
Page 7 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
8
microorganisms. The filtrate was immediately freeze dried under a vacuum system to 160
obtain the powdered root exudate. 161
NMR Sample Preparation. The leaves of cucumber plants exposed to different levels of 162
nano-Cu were collected after day seven. The leaves tissues were immediately frozen 163
using liquid nitrogen, ground, and then freeze dried for 2 days using a lyophilizer 164 (Labconco, MO, USA). The extraction method by Kim et al.37 was followed. 165
Specifically, 50 mg of the frozen dried leaf tissues were mixed with 0.75 ml of CD3OD 166 and 0.75 ml of KH2PO4 buffer in D2O (pH 6.0) containing 0.1% TSP (wt/wt). The 167 mixture was vortexed for 1 min, and ultrasonicated for 20 min at room temperature. After 168
sonication, the mixture was centrifuged for 15 min. The entire 0.8 ml of supernatant was 169
transferred to a 5 mm NMR tube. Extraction of the freeze dried root exudate samples 170
followed the same method. 171 NMR Analysis and Data Processing. The 1H NMR spectra of cucumber leaf extracts 172
and root exudates were measured on a Bruker AVANCE III 800 MHz SB NMR 173 Spectrometer. Specifically, one-dimensional (1D) 1H NMR spectra of leaf extracts and 174
root exudates were obtained using a 14.5µs 90° pulse, 3s relaxation delay, 20ppm spectral 175
width, and 2s acquisition time, with 200 transients of 64k data points collected over a 16 176
min data accumulation time. The residual water signal was suppressed with pre-saturation 177
during the relaxation delay. The resulting spectra were phase and baseline corrected and 178
then chemical shift calibrated using the Bruker Topspin 3.1 software. 179
The 1D NMR spectra were converted to an appropriate format for multivariate 180
analysis using MNOVA (Version 10, Mestrelab Research, S.L). For NMR data, the 181
chemical shift region of significance between 0.5 ppm and 10.0 ppm was divided into 182
Page 8 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
9
small bins of equal width (0.04 ppm bin size) with the region from 4.7 ppm to 4.85 ppm 183
excluded to eliminate the small residual signal from water. Finally about 240 buckets 184
were generated for each sample. Principal components analyses (PCA) of the binned 185
NMR data were conducted with the PCA module of MNOVA. For the bins with 186
significant changes across a given set of samples, the responsible metabolites were 187
identified with Chenomx NMR Suite 7.0 (Chenomx Inc.). 188
Statistical Analyses of Other Data. For the assay of biomass, Cu concentration, mineral 189
nutrient concentration, significant differences between treatment means were evaluated 190
by one way ANOVA followed by Tukey-Kramer post-hoc tests, performed by SPSS. The 191
effects of nano-Cu treatment were considered statistically significant when p < 0.05. Data 192
are presented as mean ± standard errors (n=4). 193
Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS) Analysis of Root Exudates. The 194
freeze dried root exudate samples were subjected to gas chromatography time of flight 195
mass spectrometer-mass spectrometry (GC-TOF-MS) analysis at the Genome Center 196
Core Services, University of California Davis to identify the metabolites. Description of 197 the instrument has been reported previously38. The sample extraction method and 198 chromatography sample preparation were previously reported by Fiehn et al39. 199
200
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION 201
Impact of nano-Cu on Cucumber Growth. After seven days exposure to 10 and 20 202
mg/L of nano-Cu, cucumber plants exhibited significant decrease in root length compared 203
to the control. Exposure to 10 and 20 mg/L of nano-Cu also resulted in root biomass 204
reduction by 11.7% and 30.2% respectively (Figure S1), but only the effect at 20 mg/L 205
Page 9 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
10
was statistically significant (p ≤ 0.05). Similar results have been reported in zucchini, 206 squash, wheat, lettuce, and alfalfa10, 11, 40, 41. Stampoulis et al.40 observed reduced root 207
elongation of zucchini seeds after exposure to 1,000 mg/L Cu NPs. Musante and White 208
reported that exposure to Cu NPs at 100 and 500 mg/L resulted in significant biomass 209 reduction of squash41. Lee et al also found Cu NPs at 200 mg/L affected wheat root 210 elongation10. More recently, Hong et al.11 reported that Cu NPs at a concentration of 20 211
mg/L significantly reduced the root length of alfalfa and lettuce. It has been reported that 212 copper toxicity results from inhibition or activation of some enzymes in the root zone42. 213
For instance, Kennedy and Gonsalves reported Cu inhibited ATPase activity in the 214 plasma membrane of Zea mays roots43. Previous studies showed copper toxicity triggered 215 oxidative damage and increased the antioxidative enzymes44-46. 216
Compared to the roots, nano-Cu had no statistically significant impact on stem and 217
leaf biomass. This is consistent with previous reports that roots are the most vulnerable 218 organ under nano-Cu stress10, 47, 48. Lee et al. reported that nano-Cu at 200 mg/L affected 219
the root length of wheat, while the threshold to induce shoot length reduction is 800 mg/L. 220 CuSO4 was observed to inhibit root growth but not shoot growth in rice seedlings 47. 221 Fernandes and Henriques48 attributed the differential effect of Cu on root and shoot 222
growth to the fact that Cu is mainly bioaccumulated in roots compared to shoots. 223 However, Hong et al, demonstrated that the Cu toxicity is a species-specific response11. 224
They showed that although the Cu concentration was high in alfalfa shoots, compared to 225 lettuce, there was no shoot length reduction11. 226
Cu Uptake and Translocation. In all tissues including root, stem and leaves, Cu 227
concentration in plants treated with 10 and 20 mg/L of nano-Cu were significantly higher 228
Page 10 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
11
than that in the control (Figure 1). This indicates that copper (in either form) was taken up 229
by and transported from root to stem and leaves within seven days. The distribution 230
patterns of Cu in different tissues in both control and nano-Cu treated plants are similar: 231
Cu was predominant in roots (89~92%) followed by stems (8~11%), and leaves 232
(0.2~0.5%). This indicates that Cu was sequestered primarily in the root compartment, 233
and only a small percentage was transported to upper tissues. This is consistent with 234 previous reports showing that Cu is located primarily in roots of alfalfa and lettuce11. 235
It is interesting to note that the stem/root translocation factors (Cu in stems/Cu in 236
roots) have the tendency to increase with increasing nano-Cu concentration, while the 237
leaf/stem translocation factors (Cu in leaves/Cu in stems) decrease (Figure S2). This 238
indicates cucumber plants tend to retain/sequester more Cu in their stems. The 239
mechanism underlying this phenomenon is complex, and still unclear. We hypothesize 240
that this is a detoxification or active protective process for the plants to avoid the damage 241
to more vulnerable tissue-root and leafs. It has been shown that copper in xylem sap is 242 almost 100% bound to amino acids49-52. The stem may secret more ligands, e.g., carboxyl 243
and amino groups, organic acids, glutathione, cysteine, to complex or chelate with Cu 244 when it is in excess53. Liao et al.52 showed evidence that more than 99.6% of total Cu in 245
the xylem sap of tomato plants was in a complexed form, with the xylem sap producing 246
amino acids to chelate Cu and hinder its translocation to leaves. These findings with Cu 247
are consistent with previous reports that plants are able to minimize the adverse effects of 248
excess metals by regulating their distribution and translocation within their organs or 249 cells53, 54. 250
Page 11 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
12
Effects of nano-Cu on Mineral Nutrient Metabolism. As shown in Table 1, In the 251
presence of nano-Cu, nutrient elements were markedly affected. The concentrations of 252
Na, P, S, K, Mo and Zn decreased in all cucumber tissues in exposed plants. Except K in 253
roots (p=0.073) and leaves (p=0.087), and Na in leaves (p=0.168), all the decreases were 254
statistically significant (p ≤ 0.05). In addition, nano-Cu decreased Fe and Mg uptake in 255
roots, but not in stems and leaves. Reduced uptake of P and S and Fe in lettuce and alfalfa 256 by nano-Cu was also observed in hydroponic systems11. Since the applied nano-Cu 257
concentrations in the two studies are similar, cucumber seems to be more sensitive to 258
nano-Cu than lettuce or alfalfa, probably because of its higher transpiration rate that 259
carries more Cu to plant cells. Our previous study showed that nCeO2 and nZnO NPs 260 decreased Cu and Mo content in cucumber fruits; however, neither nCeO2 nor nZnO 261 affected mineral element accumulation in corn cobs12, 13. 262
The decrease of K concentration in all tissues may be the result of leakage mediated 263 by ion channels. Murphy demonstrated that Cu promotes K+ efflux rather than inhibiting 264 K+ uptake in Arabidopsis seedlings31. Several studies have shown that iron uptake is 265 decreased by excess Cu55-57. Hong et al., also found nano-Cu significantly decreased Fe 266 uptake in lettuce. Waters and Armbrust58 found that high Cu supply inhibited the activity 267
of ferric reductase, which is an indicator of Fe demand. This led to decreased demand for 268
Fe by the plant, which subsequently led to less Fe accumulation. 269 Decreased P is due to the formation of Cu-phosphate complexes at the root surface59. 270 However, some studies11, 60 showed the up-regulation of S in the presence of nano-Cu or 271
other stressors, which is quite different from our finding. It is possible that nano-Cu 272
damages the root cell membrane and leads to leakage of many ions. These elements 273
Page 12 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
13
participate in respiration and photosynthesis and in some enzyme system functions. The 274
decrease of these minerals may lead to other metabolic changes. For example, Cu-275
induced Fe deficiency can contribute to decreased leaf chlorophyll content and reduced 276 photosynthesis61. Reichman42 reported that the chlorotic symptoms on young leaves of 277
plant experiencing Cu toxicity could be an induced Fe-deficiency. 278
Effect of Nano-Cu on Overall Metabolic Profile of Cucumber Leaves. Principal 279
component analysis (PCA) was performed as a first step to provide a general overview of 280 trends, grouping and outliers in the 1H NMR data14, 16, 19. PCA of the metabolomics data 281
set extracted from 12 cucumber leaf samples produced three principal components (PCs) 282
which explained more than 66.9% of the total variance (PC1, PC2 and PC3 explained 283
34.1%, 18.8% and 14.0%, respectively). The score plot from PC1 and PC2 reflect that 284
leaf tissues from the control and nano-Cu treated plants were clearly separated from each 285
other by PC2 (Figure S3) reflecting differences in metabolic profiles. However, no 286
difference was found between 10 ppm and 20 ppm treatments, indicating that nano-Cu at 287
either level changed the pattern of metabolites in cucumber leaves. 288
The PCA loading plot identified the regions of the NMR spectra that contribute to the 289
observed differences in PC scores. Further, bins with high weighting score were selected 290
and subjected to one-way ANOVA to identify metabolites significantly regulated due to 291
nano-Cu stress. A total of 25 bins were found to be significantly altered in cucumber 292
leaves in response to nano-Cu exposure (P-value≤ 0.05) (data not shown). 293
Identification of Metabolites and Metabolite Pathways Altered by Nano-Cu. In total, 294
22 metabolites were identified as significantly altered using Chenomx (Table 2). Most of 295
the altered metabolites are secondary metabolites. Among the five up-regulated 296
Page 13 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
14
metabolites, 4-aminobutyrate (GABA), acetylglucosamine and phenyllactate have 297
previously been shown to be related to stress response. GABA is a non-protein amino 298
acid. In plants there are numerous observations of a rapid accumulation of GABA in 299 response to biotic and abiotic stress62-64. Zulak reported that GABA levels were rapidly 300 increased in elicitor-treated opium poppy cell cultures.65. Acetylglucosamine, an amino-301
sugar, plays an important role in cell signaling. It has been reported that inflammation 302
induced by bacterial infection can result in increased release of amino sugars from 303 mammalian host cells66. Phenyllactate and p-hydroxyphenyllactate were found to 304 decrease ROS production in both mitochondria and neutrophils67. 305
Those metabolites were further analyzed with MetaboAnaylst 2.0 306
(http://www.metaboanalyst.ca/MetaboAnalyst/) to identify the major perturbed metabolic 307 pathways induced by nano-Cu. The pathway impact value threshold was set as 0.1.49 308
Results showed that none of the pathways were disturbed by nano-Cu in cucumber 309
leaves. 310
Root Exudate Metabolomics Analysis. Extracts of root exudate from control and nano-311 Cu treated plants were analyzed by 1H-NMR followed by PCA analysis. PCA analysis 312
revealed clear separation in the root exudate metabolomics profiles collected from control 313
and nano-Cu treated cucumber plants along PC1 (Figure S4). The PCA loadings identify 314
the regions of NMR spectra that contribute to the differences in PC1 (Figure S5 A-C). In 315
the region of organic acids (δ 3.00-0.00), a number of bin areas increased in the presence 316 of nano-Cu, indicating nano-Cu and released Cu2+ increased the level of a number of 317
amino acids or organic acids (Fig S5 A). The aromatic region (δ 10.00-6.00) comprises 318 many characteristic signals of secondary metabolites37, which play a crucial role in plant 319
Page 14 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
15
defense to environmental stress68. As shown in Figure S5 C, nano-Cu/Cu ions altered the 320
pattern of some secondary metabolites. We further identified those bins to corresponding 321
compounds. However, due to the extremely low concentration and high base line, it was 322
difficult to link those bin areas to specific compounds using the Chenomx NMR Suite. 323
Thus, GC-MS was used for identification and quantification. A total of 156 metabolites in 324
root exudates were identified by GC-MS. 325
In order to visualize the general differences between control and nano-Cu treated plants, 326
the 156 identified metabolites were normalized and analyzed by Partial Least Squares -327 Discriminant Analysis (PLS-DA) using online resources69, which is a supervised 328
clustering method to maximize the separation between groups. The score plot (Figure 2) 329
shows that cucumber root exudate exposed to different concentrations of nano-Cu are 330
clearly separated along the first principal axis (PC1), which explained 30.4% of the total 331
variability. This indicates nano-Cu considerably altered the metabolic profiles of 332
cucumber root exudate, which is consistent with NMR data. Using parameters of variable 333 importance in projection (VIP) score70, a total of 56 metabolites were found to be 334
responsible for this separation (data not shown). For the metabolites of interest, 335
Hierarchical Clusters Analysis (HCA) was performed by grouping the samples into 336
clusters based on the similarity of their metabolite abundance profiles. Figure 3 presents 337
the resulting heat map for the selected metabolites, which indicates that some metabolites, 338
including lysine, threonine, phenylalanine, glycine, serine, proline, isoleucine, alanine, 339
valine, leucine, beta-alanine, 4-hydroxybenzoate, benzoic acid, 2-hydroxyvaleric acid, 340
pelargonic acid, salicylic acid, lactic acid, were up-regulated by nano-Cu. However, some 341
metabolites were down-regulated by nano-Cu, including parabanic acid, 3-(4-342
Page 15 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
16
hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid, N-acetylmannosamine, erythritol, pimelic acid, 343
dehydroascorbic acid, N-acetyl-D-galactosamine, fructose-6-phosphate, hexonic acid, 344
vanillic acid, and citric acid. In the following section, we categorized those metabolites 345
into five groups: amino acids, organic acids, fatty acid, phenolic compounds and discuss 346
them separately. 347
Amino Acids. Eleven amino acids, including Alanine (Ala), beta alanine (β-Ala), 348
Glycine (Gly), Isoline (Ile), Leucine (Leu), Lysine (Lys), Phenylalanine (Phe), Proline 349
(Pro), Serine (Ser), Threonine (Thr), and Valine (Val), were significantly up-regulated in 350
response to nano-Cu in a dose-dependent way (Figure 3 and Figure S6). The increased 351
exudation of amino acids is likely an active defense response of the cucumber plant. The 352
up-regulated amino acids can provide many binding sites for copper, hindering the 353
translocation from the root cell membrane. Previous studies showed that amino acids play 354 an important role in chelating Cu2+ 52, 71. It is reported that amino acid complexes formed 355 with other metals, e.g. Ni are much more stable than those with carboxylic acids72. Cu in 356 the roots of Cu-tolerant A. maritima exist as a Cu-proline complex73. EXAFS spectra 357
demonstrated Cu(II) complexation with the non-proteogenic amino acid nicotianamine, 358 which shows very high affinity for Cu(II) 74. Kupper et al. assumed that plants keep 359
dissolved metals out of the cytoplasm and sequester/complex them into the vacuole or 360 cell wall75, 76. The up-regulated amino acids may also reflect an attempt by the cucumber 361
plants to sequester Cu in stems. Although stem metabolites were not analyzed, it is 362 possible that amino acids are also secreted in the xylem sap to bind with Cu2+ in the 363
transpiration stream. It is reported that more than 99% Cu in tomato and chicory xylem 364 sap was in a bound form with histidine (His) and nicotianamine (NA)52. Amino acids in 365
Page 16 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
17
root exudate not only bind metals, but also serve as signaling molecules and have an 366 antioxidant defense function71. 367
If the upregulation of these amino acids is an active defense of cucumber plant to excess 368
nano-Cu/Cu ions, the increased amino acids possibly will decrease the uptake of Cu by 369
cucumber plants. In order to verify this hypothesis, two-week-old cucumber plants were 370
cultivated in 20 mg/L nano-Cu nutrient solution with different levels of Ser for 48 hours. 371
Interestingly, Cu accumulation in roots decreased with increasing Ser concentration, even 372
though the free Cu ions in nutrient solution were much higher in the presence of Ser 373
(Figure 4). After the plants were removed, the pH in nutrient solutions was determined. 374
As shown in Figure 5, the pH decreased from 6.37 to 6.01 as the Ser concentration 375
increased from 0 to 25 mM, which may explain why more Cu ions were released in the 376
presence of Ser (nano-Cu with different concentrations of Ser) compared to the control 377
(only nano-Cu). Those results strongly indicate that amino acids are possibly released to 378
detoxify nano-Cu by binding with Cu ions. However, we cannot rule out the possibility 379
that up-regulation of some amino acids was due to membrane damage, which caused the 380
leakage. 381
Organic Acids. Organic acids are strong cation chelators, which play an important role in 382
facilitating mineral element uptake and sequester or exclude toxic metals. Several studies 383
have shown that citric, oxalic, and succinic acids are involved in the detoxification of 384 various dissolved metals77-80. GC-MS results showed citric, succinic, malic, and fumaric 385
acids were the most abundant low molecular weight organic acids in cucumber root 386
exudates, which are consistent with previous reports on organic acid composition in 387 cucumber root exudates81, 82. Surprisingly, patterns of succinic, malic, and fumaric acids 388
Page 17 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
18
were not changed by nano-Cu (data not shown), which indicates those organic acids did 389
not respond to Cu stress. In contrast, citric acid, the most abundant organic acid, was 390
down-regulated by nano-Cu (Figure 2). Citric acid in root exudate decreased 5x at 10 391
ppm nano-Cu and 60x at 20 ppm in treated cucumber plants compared to the control. It is 392
known that organic acids play an important role in restricting the passage of metals across 393
the root, due to their strong affinity to form stable extracellular complexes with Cu, Al, 394 and Cd78, 80. Other reports showed organic acids in the rhizosphere help solubilize 395 minerals and facilitate their uptake by the plant23. Citric acid has been shown to assist 396 copper uptake in a moderate-accumulator plant (Brassica napus L)83. The down-397
regulation of citric acid is possibly an active process to decrease the dissolution, uptake 398
and translocation of Cu into cucumber tissues, or it could represent a shift in metabolism 399
in the tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle). 400
As mentioned before, citric acid can play a dual role: it can either mobilize metals to 401 accelerate uptake in plants that are deficient in some elements,23 or it can complex with 402 metals to hinder their translocation.78,80 In this study, we hypothesized that citric acid 403
played a role in mobilizing Cu ions release from nano-Cu, increasing Cu accumulation in 404
cucumber plants. To confirm this hypothesis, we conducted an additional experiment in 405
which we exposed cucumber plants to 20 mg/L nano-Cu at different concentrations of 406
citric acid (details shown in Supporting Information). We found that the pH of the 407
hydroponic system decreased from 6.37 (20 mg/L nano-Cu without citric acid) to 5.28 408
(20 mg/L nano-Cu with 6.25 mM citric acid). This decrease in pH led to increased 409
dissolved Cu ions to concentrations that were 8 times higher than in the control (20 mg/L 410
nano-Cu without citric acid) (Figure S7 A and B). This result indicates that citric acid has 411
Page 18 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
19
a strong ability to dissolve nano-Cu by decreasing the system pH. Therefore, it not 412
surprising that Cu levels in cucumber plants grown in 20 mg/L nano-Cu in presence of 413
6.25 mM citric acid were 4 times higher than that in plants grown in 20 ppm nano-Cu 414
without additional citric acid (Figure S7 C). However, it is noteworthy that citric acid at 415
this concentration may damage biological membranes and lead to passive uptake of Cu 416
through leaky membranes. At least, these additional experiments demonstrate that citric 417
acid increased nano-Cu dissolution in cucumber plants. Taken together, the up-regulation 418
of amino acids and down-regulation of citric acid are likely plant strategies to hinder the 419
uptake of Cu and detoxify the Cu toxicity. 420
Fatty Acids. The release of fatty acids from the membrane is involved in plant tolerance 421 to biotic and abiotic stresses84-87. Pelargonic acid was up-regulated in root exudates after 422
exposure to nano-Cu (Figure 2). Pelargonic acid is a natural non-selective herbicide, 423 which can disrupt intercellular pH and membrane integrity causing rapid cell death88. 424
Evidence has shown that pelargonic acid participates in stress response and can be an 425 indicator of root membrane damage89, 90. The increased pelargonic acids in nano-Cu 426
treated root exudates may be an indicator of membrane damage. Copper also interferes 427 with fatty acid metabolism91. 428
Phenolic Compounds. Phenolics are secondary metabolites with an important role in 429 stress response92. The concentration of salicylic and benzoic acids were up-regulated in 430
the presence of nano-Cu/Cu, especially salicylic acid (Figure 2). Both compounds are 431
reported to have antioxidant and antifungal activities and play a crucial role in plant 432 defense against a variety of biotic and abiotic stressors93, 94. The concentrations of 433
salicylic acid in root exudate of 10 ppm and 20 ppm nano-Cu treated plants were 13 and 434
Page 19 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
20
26 times higher than the control. It is reported that salicylic acid serves as an internal 435 signaling molecule in the activation of plant defense after pathogen attack95. Previous 436
studies also suggested salicylic acid treatment significantly reduced malondialdehyde 437
(MDA) and H2O2 concentrations in the roots and leaves of rice (Oryza sativa L.) under 438 Cu stress, therefore alleviating Cu toxicity96. In addition, 4-hydroxybenzoate, a phenolic 439
derivative of benzoic acid, which is a secondary metabolite and also plays a key role in 440
stress response, was up-regulated by exposure to nano-Cu. The up-regulation of these 441
three phenolics is possibly a self-protection mechanism of cucumber to nano-Cu exposure 442
at these levels. 443
Other Down-Regulated Metabolites. As shown in Figure 2, most of the down-regulated 444
compounds are sugar-related metabolites, which might explain why citric acid exudation 445
decreased as it was preserved for the TCA cycle. It is interesting to find that the level of 446
dehydroascorbic acid (DHA) in nano-Cu treated root exudates is apparently down-447
regulated (Figure 2). DHA is known to participate in the plant defense against oxidative 448 stress97, and it is also an oxidized form of ascorbic acid. Dehydroascorbate is an 449
intermediate product of the reaction between ascorbic acid and ROS, and can be oxidized 450
to threonic acid. Thus, the down-regulation of DHA is an indicator that ROS was 451
triggered by nano-Cu in the rhizosphere and a response to oxidative stress occurred. It is 452
possible that the membrane damage occurred due to lipid peroxidation induced by ROS. 453
454
Environmental Implications. Since the nutritional sources of microbes in the 455 rhizosphere come from root exudates,98 the altered pattern of amino acids, carboxylic 456
acids, phenolics, and sugar metabolites may possibly affect microbial activities and 457
Page 20 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
21
communities in the rhizosphere. Yuan et al.99 revealed that n-CeO2 did not affect soil 458 bacterial communities in the absence of soybean plants, but did affect them in the 459
presence of soybean plants, likely through the change of quantity and composition of root 460
exudates. Our results indicate that nano-Cu altered the metabolite profile in cucumber 461
root exudates, and this change may alter the mutually-beneficial feedback interactions 462
between plant and microbes in the rhizosphere. 463
Root exudate as a hidden part of plant defense system, has been neglected or 464
underestimated in previous studies investigating plant-related nanotoxicity. In this study, 465
the profiling analysis of root exudate metabolites revealed important detoxification 466 mechanisms of cucumber plants to nano-Cu induced stress. In addition, 1H NMR and GC-467
MS based metabolomics provided a comprehensive understanding of the changes in 468
metabolites induced by exposure to nano-Cu, and this powerful combination of analytical 469
techniques may be very useful in revealing effects of other NPs on different plant tissues, 470
even at sub-lethal NP concentrations. The findings reflect the situation in hydroponic 471
media, which is quite relevant for cucumber production in many parts of the world. 472
However, the results may be different in soil media. Further studies are clearly needed to 473
elucidate the contribution of membrane damage to up-regulated metabolites in root 474
exudate. 475
476

sections.heading: TOF-MS.
sections.text:
Figure 3. Heat map generated by hierarchical cluster analysis of GC-MS data of root exudate. Centroid method and Euclidean distance were used for clustering analysis. GCMS data was log2 transformed and raw scaled prior cluster analysis. Red rectangles
indicate a significant decrease in metabolite content, and green rectangles, a significant
increase in metabolite content. The dendrograms reveal the relationships between the
different treatments (control, 10 ppm nano-Cu, 20 ppm nano-Cu) based on their
metabolites abundance levels. The four control samples were clearly separated from
nano-Cu treatments. Two nano-Cu treatments were mixed together indicating similar
changes of metabolites after treatment. Two nano-Cu samples at 20 ppm were clustered
together and showed larger changes for those metabolites that responded to the nano-Cu
treatment. Metabolites with similar abundance patterns are also clustered together
Page 32 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
horizontally and practically formed two big clusters coresponding to up-regulated and
down-regulated metabolites.
Figure 4. Cu uptake in cucumber tissues and nutrient solution. The black square dots represent the Cu concentrations in the nutrient solution at harvest. Two-week-old
cucumber seelings were cultivated in half strengh Hogland nutrient solution containing
20 mg/L nano-Cu with different levels of serine (0, 6.25, 12.5, and 25 mM) for 48 h. At
harvest, the Cu concentrations in plant tissues and remaining hydroponic solution were
analyzed by ICP-MS.
